New Records: The Dodgers became the first team to come back from five or more runs down in a World Series-clinching win.
Freddie Freeman hit a two-run single to tie the Fall Classic record of 12 RBIs set by Bobby Richardson over seven games in 1960.
Key Match Events: Aaron Judge and Jazz Chisholm Jr pounced on Dodgers starter Jack Flaherty with back-to-back homers in the first inning.
The Dodgers piled on five unearned runs to go level in the fifth behind a series of dreadful errors from the Yankees.
The Yankees nosed ahead 6-5 on a Stanton sacrifice fly in the sixth, but the Dodgers took the lead for good in the eighth on a pair of sacrifice flies by Gavin Lux and Mookie Betts.
Post-Match Reflections: New York manager Aaron Boone said after the defeat: 'As I said to the guys, obviously it stings now, but this is going to sting forever.'
Freddie Freeman was a straightforward choice for Most Valuable Player honors.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers deployed no fewer than seven relievers to keep the resurgent Yankee lineup at bay, setting a World Series record for a clinching win.
The Dodgers, whose 98 regular-season victories were the most in the majors, became the first team to come back from five or more runs down in a World Series-clinching win.
Others: Shohei Ohtani finished his first World Series with a.105 batting average (2-for-19) with no RBIs after separating his shoulder during a stolen base attempt in Game 2.
